security: These documents detail CIA surveillance and intelligence-gathering operations targeting Soviet officials, including Valentin Loginov, in Mexico City. They reveal the use of informants (LICOZY/5, PBSWING officer, LIFIRE), photographic surveillance (LILYRIC), and passport information obtained through LITEMPO. Sharing this information could compromise intelligence sources and methods, potentially disrupting ongoing operations and damaging relations with foreign governments.
summary: These documents detail CIA efforts to monitor Valentin Sergeyevich Loginov, a suspected KGB officer in the Soviet Embassy in Mexico City, including his contacts, travel, and family. They also mention an unidentified visitor to the Soviet Embassy and a U.S. student traveling to the Soviet Union via Mexico, raising suspicions of concealed motives.
summary_one_paragraph: These classified dispatches and messages reveal CIA surveillance of Valentin Sergeyevich Loginov, a suspected KGB officer stationed at the Soviet Embassy in Mexico City. The documents detail his physical description, family information, travel history, and contacts with other Soviet officials and potential informants. The CIA used various sources, including LILYRIC, LICOZY/5, and a PBSWING officer, to gather intelligence on Loginov and his activities. Also included are details about an unidentified visitor to the Soviet Embassy and a U.S. student who traveled to the Soviet Union via Mexico in what appeared to be an attempt to conceal his trip from U.S. authorities.
title: REDWOOD - Valentin Sergeyevich LOGINOV (201-285412) - Monitoring and Intelligence Gathering
sender: Chief, SR Division via Chief, WH Division
